sentence.text: ﻿The patient's 29-year-old G1 Caucasian mother was originally referred to a maternal fetal medicine center at 29 weeks of gestation for fetal anomalies.
By transabdominal ultrasonography, the female fetus appeared to have a right-sided stomach and left-sided liver.
The heart appeared structurally normal but mildly enlarged; these findings were confirmed by a fetal echocardiogram.
The fetus also was noted to have an abnormally shaped cranium (Fig. 1).

At 33 weeks of gestation, further ultrasound examination documented polyhydraminos, mild bilateral ventriculomegaly of the lateral ventricles measuring 14 mm (normal <10 mm), an enlarged third ventricle at 8 mm (normal <3.5 mm), scalp edema, and an abnormally shaped cranial vault with temporal widening [Creasy et al., 2009].
The fetus also had a globally enlarged heart and a left abdominal mass measuring 3.3 cm × 3.6 cm.
An amniocentesis done at 33 + 2 weeks gestation revealed a 46,XX karyotype.
At 35 weeks of gestation, the fetal heart filled 50% of the chest.
The lateral cerebral ventricles remained proportionately the same sizes.
The fetal weight was estimated to be >95th centile, at 3,865 g.

The final ultrasound study performed at 35 weeks of gestation demonstrated an abdominal cyst, which measured 8.0 cm × 8.3 cm The proposita was born by cesarean at term due to her size and macrocephaly.
Birth weight was 4,840 g (>97 centile) and length 51.0 cm (75th–95th centile), and occipital frontal circumference (OFC) was 36 cm (+2 SD above the mean).
She had craniosynostosis with overlapping metopic and sagittal sutures, temporal narrowness, reverse epicanthal folds, and ocular hypotelorism (Fig. 2).
Ears were slightly posteriorly angulated with bilateral ear pits present.
She had wide-spaced inverted nipples with the left nipple being lower set than the right.
An abdominal-wall hernia (4 cm width) was approximately 2 cm above the umbilicus.
The hernia became larger and tense after positive pressure ventilation (Fig. 2).

In addition, the patient had short middle phalanges, presence of only two finger creases on digits 2, 3, and 5 bilaterally, broad and laterally placed thumbs, pre-axial polysyndactyly of the feet, and 2–3 toe syndactyly and bilateral 2–3 toe syndactyly.
Neonatal abdominal ultrasound confirmed the presence of a large cyst and noted that the liver was set high in the chest adjacent to the heart.
An MRI of the patient's head showed diffuse cerebral deficiency and global white matter volume loss.
Both of these abnormalities were most pronounced in the inferior frontal and anterior temporal lobes.
A head ultrasound study showed prominent ventricles.
An MRI of the abdomen revealed a large abdominal cyst measuring 11.1 cm × 7.0 cm × 9.3 cm, a right-sided spleen, and a right-sided stomach, consistent with the ultrasound findings of heterotaxy.
Echocardiogram confirmed a moderately enlarged but structurally normal heart.

Radiographs showed small and “dysplastic” middle phalanges of the third and fourth digits of hands and bilateral polysyndactyly of the first toe with two fully formed distal phalanges and “dysplastic” extra metatarsals.
At operation a left ovarian follicular cyst measured 8.2 cm × 4.5 cm × 2.2 cm and contained over 400 ml of fluid.
The right ovary, Fallopian tubes, and uterus were normal.
Heterotaxy with malrotation of the stomach, small and large intestine, and liver was confirmed, and the duodenum had abnormal fixation.
The small intestines resided on the right side with the entire colon on the left.
However, pancreas, gallbladder, and heart were in their normal locations.
A spleen scan at 16 days of life noted single splenic tissue and a significant portion of the liver in the upper left quadrant.
Based on the child's craniosynostosis and polysyndactyly, the diagnosis of Carpenter syndrome was made.
An echocardiogram at age four months demonstrated interruption of the inferior vena cava with azygous continuation and a small atrial septal defect with left-to-right shunting.
A head CT scan at this time indicated multifocal craniosynostosis with trigonocephaly and mild to moderate white matter loss.

A physical exam by us at five months of age noted metopic and partial sagittal synostosis, anteriorly located coronal sutures, frontal bossing, ocular hypotelorism, proptosis, shallow orbits, midface hypoplasia, slightly upslanting palpebral fissures, posteriorly rotated but normally set ears, an abdominal wall protrusion which measured 7 cm × 11 cm, abdominal laxity, wide-spaced nipples, proximally displaced thumbs, clinodactyly of digits 2–5 bilaterally, non-palpable middle phalanges of digits 2–5 bilaterally, bilateral duplication and syndactyly of the great toes, and partial syndactyly of toes 1–2 and 2–3 on the left and 2–3 on the right (Fig. 2).
Her weight was 8.33 kg, length was 66 cm, and OFC was 48.5 cm (75th centile, 75th–90th centile, and 3 SD above the mean, respectively).
